title: Least common multiple
summary: In arithmetic and number theory, the least common multiple, lowest common multiple, or smallest common multiple of two integers a and b, usually denoted by lcm(a,Â b), is the smallest positive integer that is divisible by both a and b.[1][2]  Since division of integers by zero is undefined, this definition has meaning only if a and b are both different from zero.[3]  However, some authors define lcm(a,0) as 0 for all a, which is the result of taking the lcm to be the least upper bound in the lattice of divisibility.
